motd1: The only way to do great work is to love what you do. - Steve Jobs
motd2: Code is like humor. When you have to explain it, it’s bad. - Cory House
motd3: First, solve the problem. Then, write the code. - John Johnson

README_md:
VoidShell v1.0
--------------------------
Welcome, hacker.

This is your personal information terminal.
Type 'help' to see a list of available commands.
about_md:
I'm Isra, a full-stack web developer with a passion for technology that began at age 6, when I started using Linux. Since then, I've built my path around systems, servers, and web development, working with technologies like JavaScript, PHP, Python, and environments like Linux, WSL2, and server administration (Windows/Linux).

I started creating interfaces with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, but my curiosity led me beyond the frontend. Today, I develop complete applications with a full-stack approach, integrating backend logic, automation, and good web security practices: vulnerability analysis, application hardening, and secure server maintenance.

I am also passionate about designing interfaces with a cyberpunk and futuristic aesthetic—impactful, functional visuals with personality—always prioritizing a clear and effective user experience (UX/UI).

I currently work at Entreredes Consultoría Tecnológica, where I develop web solutions, manage infrastructures, and improve the security and performance of applications.

Constantly exploring, learning, and building.
If you're interested in full-stack development, web security, or the Linux world with a technological and aesthetic perspective... I'd love to connect!

blog_post_1_title: Developing on Windows? This is the best time to try Linux.
blog_post_1_content:
If you are a developer and have not yet tried Linux as your main system, let me tell you something: you are missing a large part of the real development ecosystem.

I have been using Linux as my main system for years, and it is no coincidence. Here are some reasons why I think it is worth making the leap:

  • 🔹 More realistic development environment: Many production environments (servers, containers, etc.) run on Linux. Working on the same system helps to avoid errors and unexpected differences.
  • 🔹 Full control: Linux allows you to understand what is happening in your system. It is not a black box: it is transparent and gives you control.
  • 🔹 Native automation: UNIX environments are designed to automate tasks. Bash, cron, scripts... everything flows naturally.
  • 🔹 Lightweight and customization: You can have a system tailored to your needs, without unnecessary processes consuming resources.
  • 🔹 Learning about systems: If you want to understand how operating systems work from the inside, Linux is the way.

I'm not saying it's easy at first, but I am saying it's worth it.

📌 If you are in web development, backend or systems… Linux is not just another option. It is an advantage.
blog_post_2_title: How to teach development to practical profiles (and have them really learn)?
blog_post_2_content:
Not everyone learns the same way. And when you lead a development team, that becomes clear quickly.

In my experience, I have seen that there are especially practical profiles. They do not need an encyclopedia, but to understand the why and how of each step. For them, theory without real application does not work.

That is why, when I train new team members, I am clear about this:

  • ✅ Visualize the problem: I always have a whiteboard nearby. It allows me to clearly outline flows, architectures or errors. The visual accelerates understanding.
  • ✅ Solve with them: No just watching. I give them real problems and guide them as they try, fail and find solutions. This is how knowledge is consolidated.
  • ✅ Ask more than answer: Many times, a good question generates more learning than a detailed explanation.
  • ✅ Review together: Real-time feedback, looking at code together, is a very powerful learning tool.

Training is not just teaching: it is knowing how to adapt knowledge to each mind.

And in development, that makes the difference between someone who complies... and someone who really understands.
man_help_description: Displays a list of all available commands in the terminal.
man_ls_description: Lists the files and directories within the specified DIRECTORY. If no directory is specified, it lists the contents of the current directory.
man_cat_description: Reads the specified FILE and displays its content on the standard output. It is used to view the content of text files.
man_cd_description: Changes the current working directory to the specified DIRECTORY. If no directory is specified, it defaults to the user's home directory (~/home/glitchbane). Use '..' to go to the parent directory.
man_tree_description: Recursively displays the contents of the specified DIRECTORY in a tree-like format. If no directory is specified, it starts from the current directory.
man_scan_description: Simulates scanning a target host (IP address or domain name) to discover open and closed TCP ports. This is a simulation and does not perform a real network scan.
man_decrypt_description: Simulates the decryption of a file with the '.enc' extension. It displays an animation and then reveals the supposed original content of the file.
man_connect_description: Simulates a connection to a remote system. Changes the prompt to indicate that the user is on the remote host. Use 'exit' to close the connection.
man_htop_description: Simulates an interactive system monitor showing a list of running processes and their resource usage. Press 'q' to exit. This command is only available on desktop.
man_top_description: Alias for 'htop'. Simulates an interactive system monitor. Press 'q' to exit. This command is only available on desktop.
man_neofetch_description: Displays a summary of the system's (the portfolio owner's) information next to an ASCII art logo.
man_cowsay_description: Generates an ASCII art cow that says the provided MESSAGE. If no message is provided, it says a default phrase.
man_history_description: Displays a list of the commands that have been previously executed in the current session.
man_switch_description: Changes the color scheme of the terminal. Run the command without arguments to see a list of available themes.
man_lang_description: Changes the display language of the terminal. Supported languages are 'es' (Spanish) and 'en' (English).
man_clear_description: Clears all the previous output from the terminal screen, providing a clean prompt at the top.
man_date_description: Prints the current system date and time to the standard output.
man_whoami_description: Prints the user name associated with the current effective user ID. In this case, it displays the portfolio owner's name and alias.
man_about_description: Displays a detailed summary about the portfolio owner. Equivalent to 'cat ~/Documents/about.md'.
man_resume_description: Displays a summary of the owner's work experience and education. Equivalent to 'cat ~/Documents/resume.md'.
man_skills_description: Lists the technical skills of the portfolio owner. Equivalent to 'cat ~/Documents/skills.md'.
man_experience_description: Displays a detailed list of the owner's work experience. Equivalent to 'cat ~/Documents/experience.md'.
man_education_description: Displays the owner's educational background. Equivalent to 'cat ~/Documents/education.md'.
man_project-list_description: Shows links to the owner's project portfolio and GitHub profile.
man_project_description: Displays detailed information about one of the main projects. Run the command without arguments to see a list of available projects.
man_contact_description: Shows professional contact information. Equivalent to 'cat ~/contact.md'.
man_social_description: Shows links to social media profiles like LinkedIn and GitHub. Equivalent to 'cat ~/social.md'.
man_echo_description: Prints the specified TEXT to the standard output.
man_motd_description: Displays a random quote or a famous phrase related to technology and programming.
man_blog_description: Allows interacting with the blog. Use 'blog ls' to list all available posts. Use 'blog read <POST_SLUG>' to read a specific post.
man_man_description: Displays the user manual for the specified COMMAND.
man_sudo_description: Simulates executing a command with superuser privileges. Since you are a guest, your powers are limited, mortal.
man_wget_description: Simulates downloading a file from the provided URL. It shows a progress bar and then saves the file to the current directory.
man_weather_description: Fetches and displays the 5-day weather forecast for the specified city.
man_cal_description: Displays a calendar of the current month.
man_stats_description: Displays a list of fun and curious stats about the portfolio owner.
man_pwd_description: Prints the full filename of the current working directory.
man_credits_description: Shows a list of libraries, APIs, and other resources used to create this portfolio.
